Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Efficient Algorithms for Rectangular Layouts and Cartograms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
A "rectangular layout" L is a partition of a rectangle into a set of disjoint smaller rectangles by vertical and horizontal line segments. L is said to "represent a graph G" if the smaller rectangles correspond to the vertices of G one-to-one, and two vertices are adjacent in G if and only if their corresponding rectangles share a common boundary in L. An "area assignment function" of L is a specification of the area of each rectangle in L. L is called a "rectangular cartogram" if the areas of the rectangles in L equal to their specified areas. L is called "area-universal" if it can realize any area-assignment function.

Rectangular layouts have applications in VLSI, architectural design, computational geometry, geographic information system, and other practical fields. Extensive research works have been done in this area. But many interesting problems remain open. The PI will study several open algorithmic problems related to these structures:
(1) How to decide if a given graph G has an area-universal layout?
(2) Given an area-universal layout L and an area-assignment function a, how to compute the coordinates of the cartogram for a by using a combinatorial algorithm?
(3) Not all plane graphs have rectangular layouts. If G does not have one, how to find a representation of G by using recti-linear polygons of more complex shapes?
(4) Another useful subclass of rectangular layouts are "slicing floorplans". Many optimization problems are NP-complete for general floorplans, but polynomial time solvable for slicing floorplans. How to decide if a given graph G has slicing floorplans or not?

The PI aims to develop efficient algorithms for solving these problems. This research will make both theoretical and practical contributions. On the practical side, many problems discussed above are motivated by real-world applications. On the theoretical side, the algorithmic tools developed in this project include several important graph-theoretic constructions, and are related to some open questions in graph theory and combinatorics. While the four problems outlined above are interesting and important, they are by no means the only problems in this field. The techniques developed in this research are likely useful in solving related problems. Two graduate students will work on this project under PI's supervision. The topics covered in this research will be taught in an advanced algorithm course.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the grant period, the PI developed algorithms for solving various
problems arising from graph theory, graph drawing, and network routing
related applications. In particular, the PI conducted research on problems
of "monotone drawings" and "greedy drawings".

A main motivation of greedy drawings is its application in network
routing, one of the most fundamental algorithmic problems in network
research. Extensive efforts have been devoted to developing efficient
routing algorithms. For this problem, the PI obtained a succinct
convex greedy drawing on a polynomial size grid with respect to a
distance function that is equivalent to the Euclidean distance.
This result is in sharp contrast to the fact that all known greedy
drawings (with respect to the Euclidean distance) of planar graphs
require exponential size grids. This result provides simpler and
better greedy routing algorithms for solving network routing problems.

Monotone drawings were introduced as a new visualization paradigm
that displays the "geodesic tendency" in graphs. It is known that the
geodesic tendency is important in understanding the structure of the
graphs being displayed. For the monotone drawings of trees, the best
previously known drawing requires an O(n^1.5) x O(n^1.5) grid. Through
a sequence of improvements, the PI showed that every tree has a monotone
drawing on a grid of size 12n x 12n and showed this is asymptotically
optimal. For the monotone drawings of planar graphs, the best previously
known result is a drawing of size O(n) x O(n^2). The PI showed that the
classical Schnyder drawing for 3-connected graph is monotone with
size O(n) x O(n), and it has additional nice properties important for
applications. The PI's results on monotone drawings of trees and planar
graphs contribute to the algorithmic foundation of graph visualization
tools based on this approach.

Some of the problems studied in this project are at the crossroads of
graph theory, graph drawing and computational geometry. The results
and insights obtained in this project will benefit these fields.
Many results obtained in this project require deep insights of combinatorial
properties of the problems. The research heavily depends on "Schnyder
realizer" and "Schnyder woods", two elegant combinatorial structures with
many applications. The PI's results in this area deepen our understanding of
these concepts. The PI's work on optimal monotone drawing of trees also
requires insights related to the distribution of primitive integer vectors.

The PI has taught these topics in a graduate seminar "Graph Orientations
and its Applications in Graph Drawing". The seminar provided a bridge
between an algorithm design course and a graph theory course. Two PhD
students were supported by this NSF grant as research assistants.
hey graduated in Jan 2016 and May 2017 respectively.
